That is why they are called \"arrangements of pure lands.\This is therefore called \"the arrangement of the buddha-fields.\Subhuti, a bodhisattva who deeply understands and believes that 'all phenomena lack self, all phenomena lack self'—this is one whom the Tathagata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened Buddha calls a bodhisattva, a great being.Subhuti, what do you think? Does the Tathagata have physical eyes?Subhuti asked, \"Blessed One, what you say is true. The Tathagata possesses ordinary human eyes.\The Blessed One said, \"Subhuti, what do you think about this?\Do you think that the Buddha possesses divine vision?Subhuti said, \"Lord, this is true. The Tathagata possesses divine vision.\The Blessed One said, \"Subhuti, what do you think about this?\Do you believe the Buddha has the eye of wisdom?Subhuti replied, \"Yes, Lord, that is so.\The Tathagata possesses the eye of wisdom.The Blessed One said, \"Subhuti, what do you think about this?\Do you believe that the Buddha possesses the eye of wisdom?Subhuti then asked, \"Is that really so, Lord?\The Tathagata possesses the eye of Dharma.The Blessed One said, \"Subhuti, what do you think about this?\Do you believe the Buddha possesses the enlightened eye of a buddha?Subhuti asked, \"Is this really so, Lord?\The Tathagata possesses the Buddha's eye.The Blessed One said, \"Subhuti, what do you think about this?\Imagine if there were as many Ganges rivers as there are grains of sand in the Ganges, and then imagine if there were as many world systems as all the grains of sand in all those Ganges rivers. Would you consider that to be a great number of world systems?Subhuti asked, \"Lord, it is just as you say.\There are many such world systems.The Blessed One said, \"Subhuti, I fully understand the continuous flow of different thoughts in the minds of all the beings that exist in those world systems.\Why is this so? Subhuti, what is called \"stream of thought\" or \"stream of mind\" has been taught by the Tathagata as having no stream at all.Therefore, this is called the continuum of mind.Why is this so? Because, Subhuti, the past mind cannot be grasped.The future mind also cannot be grasped.The present moment of mind is also ungraspable.What do you think about this, Subhuti?If someone were to completely fill this vast universe of a billion worlds with the seven precious jewels and offer it as a gift, would a son or daughter of good family generate more merit from that act?Subhuti replied, \"Lord, I understand.\Many Buddhas have come before.The Blessed One said, \"Subhuti, that is right. It is exactly so.\A son or daughter of noble family generates an enormous amount of merit from this foundation.Furthermore, Subhuti, if there were such a thing as a \"heap of merit\" that was truly a heap of merit, the Tathagata would not speak of a \"heap of merit\" as a \"heap of merit.\Subhuti, what do you think?Do you think one should view the Buddha by his physical form alone?Subhuti replied, \"No, Lord, that is not so.\One should not consider someone a Buddha merely because they possess a perfect physical form.Why is this so? The Blessed One spoke of \"the perfected physical form,\" but he taught that it is not actually perfected.Therefore, this is called the complete achievement of the form body.The Blessed One said, \"Subhuti, what do you think about this?\Do you think the Buddha should be recognized by his perfect physical marks?Subhuti replied, \"No, Lord, that is not so.\One should not look for the Buddha in perfect physical characteristics.Why is that? Because the perfect marks that the Tathagata spoke of are actually not perfect marks. This is why the Tathagata called them \"perfect marks.\Therefore, this is called \"having perfect qualities\" or \"possessing excellent characteristics.\The Blessed One said, \"Subhuti, what do you think?\The Buddha does not think, \"I have taught the Dharma.\" Subhuti, do not view it this way.Since the Buddha never actually taught any dharma at all.Subhuti, if anyone says, \"The Tathagata teaches the Dharma,\" they are misrepresenting me. That would be an incorrect understanding based on something that does not exist.Why is this so? Subhuti, what we call \"teaching the Dharma\" is not actually teaching any Dharma, because there is no actual thing that can be identified as \"teaching the Dharma.\" That is why it is called \"teaching the Dharma.\Then the Venerable Subhuti addressed the Blessed One and said:Blessed One, in future times, will there be any beings who, upon hearing this kind of teaching, will truly have faith in it?The Blessed One said, \"Subhuti, they are neither sentient beings nor are they not sentient beings.\Why is this so? Subhuti, when the Tathagata speaks of \"sentient beings,\" he teaches that they do not actually exist as sentient beings.Therefore, they are called \"sentient beings.\Subhuti, what do you think?Do you think there was any particular teaching that the Buddha realized when he attained complete, perfect enlightenment?The Venerable Subhuti said, \"Blessed One, there is no particular teaching that the Tathagata has fully realized as unsurpassed, perfect enlightenment.\The Blessed One said, \"Subhuti, that is so. That is exactly so.\In that, not even the slightest thing can be found or exists.This is therefore called \"unsurpassed, perfect, complete enlightenment.\Furthermore, Subhuti, that dharma is equal.Since it has nothing equal to it and nothing superior to it, it is therefore called \"unsurpassed, perfect, complete enlightenment.\Perfect, unsurpassable enlightenment is equal to selflessness, the absence of sentient beings, the absence of life-force, and the absence of persons.Through all virtuous qualities, one becomes a fully awakened buddha.Subhuti, regarding what we call \"virtuous qualities\"—the Tathagata has taught that they are, in reality, not qualities at all.This is simply called \"virtuous qualities\" or \"virtuous phenomena.\Furthermore, Subhuti, suppose someone were to gather precious jewels of the seven kinds in quantities equal to all the Mount Merus found throughout the billion-world system, and give them away as an offering. Compare this with someone else who memorizes even a four-line verse from this Perfection of Wisdom teaching and shares it with others. The merit from the first person's generous offering wouldn't amount to even one hundredth of the merit gained by the second person. In fact, there's no comparison whatsoever between these two acts.What do you think about this, Subhuti?The Buddha never thinks, \"I have liberated all beings.\" Shariputra, one should not view it that way.Why is this so? Because, Subhuti, there are actually no beings whom the Tathagata has liberated.Subhuti, if the Thus Gone One were to think, \"I have liberated sentient beings,\" then that very thought would be the Thus Gone One clinging to a self.Holding onto the belief in sentient beings, holding onto the belief in a life force, and holding onto the belief in a person - these are all forms of clinging.Subhuti, what we call \"attachment to a self\" has been taught by the Tathagata as non-attachment. Yet ordinary, immature people cling to it.Subhuti, regarding those called \"ordinary childish beings,\" the Tathagata has taught that they are not actually beings at all.Therefore, they are called ordinary childish beings.Subhuti, what do you think?Do you think one should view the Buddha through his perfect physical marks?Subhuti replied, \"No, Lord, that is not the case.\One should not view the Tathagata [Buddha] merely by his perfect physical characteristics.The Blessed One replied, \"Exactly so, Subhuti. It is just as you say.\One should not view the Tathagata [Buddha] merely through his perfect physical marks.Subhuti, if someone were to see the Tathagata [Buddha] through his perfect physical marks, then even a universal monarch would be a Tathagata.Therefore, one should not consider someone a Buddha merely because they possess excellent physical marks.Then the Venerable Subhuti addressed the Blessed One with these words:Blessed One, as I understand what you have taught: one should not view the Tathagata merely through his perfect physical marks.Then the Blessed One spoke these verses.Those who see me as a physical form,
Those who know me through sound,
Have entered a mistaken path.Those people do not see me.The buddhas observe the true nature of reality.The enlightened guides possess the dharmakaya ultimate reality body. Since the true nature of reality cannot be understood intellectually, it cannot be fully comprehended by ordinary consciousness.Subhuti, what do you think about this?If you believe that a Tathagata becomes a fully enlightened Buddha through perfect physical marks, then Subhuti, you should not view it this way.Subhuti, no one has attained perfect enlightenment as a Tathagata, an Arhat, a Fully Enlightened One, through possessing perfect marks or characteristics.Subhuti, if you think that those who have truly entered the Bodhisattva path believe they must destroy or eliminate any particular phenomenon, this is not the correct view. Subhuti, you should not look at it that way.Those who have genuinely entered the Bodhisattva path neither break down nor reject any phenomenon.Furthermore, Subhuti, imagine a son or daughter of noble family who filled as many world systems as there are grains of sand in the Ganges River with the seven types of precious substances and gave them all away as a gift. Compare this to a bodhisattva who attains patient acceptance of the teaching that all phenomena are selfless and unborn. The merit generated by this bodhisattva would be far greater—immeasurable and incalculable in comparison.Furthermore, Subhuti, a bodhisattva should not cling to accumulations of merit.The Venerable Subhuti asked, \"Blessed One, should a bodhisattva not accumulate a collection of merit?\The Blessed One said, \"Rabhjor, you may hold on to these teachings, but do not grasp them incorrectly.\Therefore, this is called \"complete acceptance\" or \"full embrace\".Furthermore, Subhuti, if anyone says, \"The Tathagata comes or goes, stands up or sits down, or lies down to rest,\" that person does not understand the meaning of what I have taught.Why is this so? Subhuti, the \"Tathagata\" or \"Thus-Gone One\" neither goes anywhere nor comes from anywhere.Therefore, he is called the Thus-Gone One, the Destroyer of Enemies, the Perfectly Complete Buddha.Furthermore, Subhuti, suppose a son or daughter of noble family were to reduce to fine powder all the particles of earth contained in this vast universe of a billion world systems—as many particles as there are. Tell me, Subhuti, what do you think? Would that collection of tiny particles be great in number?Subhuti replied, \"Yes, Lord, that is so.\There are countless numbers of these tiny particles.Why is this so? Because, O Blessed One, if there were truly a collection of tiny particles, the Blessed One would not have called it \"a collection of tiny particles.\" That is why.Why is this so? Because what the Blessed One described as \"a collection of tiny particles\" was taught by the Thus-Gone One to be no collection at all.Therefore, this is called \"a collection of subtle particles.\The Buddha spoke of \"the great thousand triple-thousand world system,\" yet he taught that this is not truly a realm. Thus did the Buddha explain it.This is therefore called \"the great thousandfold universe\" or \"the trichiliocosm.\Why is this so? Because, Blessed One, if there is a world system, it will be grasped as a complete whole.The Buddha taught about \"grasping the whole,\" yet he also taught that there is no grasping. He taught both these things precisely because that is the truth.Therefore, this is called \"holding the entirety.\The Blessed One said, \"Subhuti, the very concept of a 'whole' is just a conventional term.\That teaching is beyond words, yet ordinary people still try to grasp it.Subhuti, if anyone says that the Tathagata taught a concept of self, they are mistaken.If someone says, \"The Buddha taught that we should view beings as real, life as real, and persons as real,\" would they be speaking truthfully?Subhuti replied, \"No, Lord, that is not so.\That is not the Buddha.Why is this so? Because when the Blessed One, the Thus-Gone One, taught about the view of a self, he actually taught it as no view at all. That is why it is called a \"view of self.\Therefore, this is what we call \"the view of a self.\The Blessed One said, \"Subhuti, those who have genuinely entered the bodhisattva path should know, see, and have faith in all phenomena in this way:\One should understand that ultimately, we should not fixate on the concept of \"dharma\" itself.Why is this so? Subhuti, what we call \"perception of phenomena\" or \"perception of dharmas\" - the Tathagata has taught that this is actually no perception at all.Therefore, this is what we call \"perceiving phenomena as phenomena.\Furthermore, Subhuti, if a bodhisattva, a great being, were to fill immeasurable and countless world systems with the seven precious substances and give them away as a gift, this would not compare to the merit generated by a son or daughter of good family who writes down even a four-line verse from this Perfection of Wisdom, memorizes it, keeps it, reads it, masters it, or thoroughly teaches it to others. The merit from the latter would be far greater—immeasurable and incalculable.How does one teach perfectly? One teaches perfectly by not teaching perfectly at all.Therefore, it is called \"perfect teaching.\See all conditioned things in this way:
Like a star, a visual distortion, a flame,
An illusion, a drop of dew, a bubble,
A dream, a flash of lightning, or a cloud.When the Blessed One had spoken these words, the Elder Subhuti, the monks, the bodhisattvas, and the fourfold assembly—the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen—along with the gods, humans, demigods, and celestial musicians of the world rejoiced at what the Buddha had taught.Praise to the words spoken by the Blessed One.The Noble Perfection of Wisdom Scripture Known as the Diamond Cutter: A Great Vehicle Sutra – CompleteHomage to the Blessed One, the Perfection of Wisdom!

Om nata datita, ilishi, ilishi, milishi, milishi, bhinayan bhinayan.

Homage to the Blessed One! Pratyam prate, iriti, iriti, mirati, miriti, shuriti, shuriti, ushuri ushuri, bhuyuye bhuyuye svaha.Reciting this essence of the Diamond Cutter Sutra just once is equivalent to reading the entire Diamond Cutter Sutra nineteen thousand times.All phenomena arise from causes. The Tathagata has explained those causes and also their cessation. This is the teaching of the Great Renunciant.

metadata.colophon: Herein is contained the Noble Perfection of Wisdom called \"The Vajra Cutter\

incipit_title.en: The Sutra of the Great Vehicle Called the Diamond Cutter AI Draft

translations.content:
Herein is contained the Noble Perfection of Wisdom called \"The Vajra Cutter\The Noble Diamond-Cutter Perfection of Wisdom: A Mahāyāna SūtraThe Noble Vajra Cutter Perfection of Wisdom Sutra of the Great VehicleI pay homage to all the Buddhas and bodhisattvas.This have self heard at one time.The Blessed One was dwelling in Śrāvastī, in Prince Jeta's Grove, Anāthapiṇḍada's park, together with a great community of monks—twelve hundred and fifty monk disciples—and together with numerous great bodhisattva great beings.Then the Blessed One, in the morning time, having donned his lower garment and dharma robes upon his body and carrying his alms bowl, proceeded to the great city of Śrāvastī for the purpose of collecting alms.Then the Blessed One walked through the great city of Śrāvastī for alms, said the food, and performed the activities associated with the meal.After renouncing his afternoon meal, the Buddha set aside his alms bowl and Dharma robes, washed his feet, and seated himself in the cross-legged posture on the prepared seat. He straightened his body, established mindfulness before him, and remained in this meditative posture.Then, numerous monks approached wherever the Blessed One was staying in Śrāvastī and arrived in his presence.They bowed their head to the feet of the Blessed One, circumambulated him three times, and then sat to one side.At that time, Venerable Subhūti was also present in the assembly, having joined the gathering and taken his seat.Then the Venerable Subhūti rose from his seat, draped his upper robe over one shoulder, and placed his right knee on the ground. Turning toward where the Blessed One was seated, he joined his palms in reverence and bowed.With these words he addressed the Blessed One.Blessed One, how wondrous it is to what extent the Tathāgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened Buddha has bestowed the supreme benefit upon bodhisattvas, the great beings. How wondrous it is, Blessed One, to what extent the Tathāgata has entrusted the highest responsibility to bodhisattvas, the great beings.

Blessed One, it is wondrous indeed! Sugata, it is wondrous indeed!Blessed One, how should one who has genuinely entered the bodhisattva vehicle abide?How should one practice?How, Blessed One, should a bodhisattva firmly hold the mind?When he had spoken thus,The Blessed One spoke thus with these words to the Venerable Subhūti.Subhūti, excellent, excellent.Subhūti, it is so. It is exactly so.The Tathāgata has embraced the great bodhisattva great beings with supreme kindness.The Tathāgata completely entrusted the Dharma to the bodhisattvas, the great beings, with the supreme entrustment.Therefore, Subhūti, listen well and thoroughly retain these teachings in your mind.I will explain to you how one who has properly entered the bodhisattva vehicle should abide, how one should accomplish the path, and how one should firmly hold the mind.\"Indeed, Blessed One, it is so,\" he said.The Venerable Subhūti listened attentively to the Blessed One, and the Blessed One spoke thus to the Venerable Subhūti:\"Subhūti, one who has genuinely entered the bodhisattva vehicle should generate this thought: 'I shall lead to complete nirvana all sentient beings who are included within the realm of sentient beings—those born from eggs, those born from wombs, those born from moisture and heat, those spontaneously born; beings with form and those without form; beings with perception, those without perception, and those neither with nor without perception—indeed, however many beings are designated by the term \"sentient being.\" I shall lead them all to the realm of nirvana without remainder.'\Thus, although immeasurable sentient beings have been brought to complete nirvana, one should generate bodhicitta thinking that not a single sentient being has actually attained nirvana.Why is that? Because if a bodhisattva maintains the perception of sentient beings as inherently existing, they should not be called a bodhisattva.Why is that? Subhūti, one who maintains the perception of sentient being, the perception of a life-force, or the perception of a person cannot be called a bodhisattva.Furthermore, Subhūti, a bodhisattva should give generosity without abiding in phenomena.One should practice generosity without abiding in anything whatsoever.One should practice generosity without abiding on form.Similarly, one should practice generosity without abiding in sound, smell, taste, tactile sensation, or dharma.Thus, Subhūti, a bodhisattva should give generosity without abiding even in the perception of characteristics.Why is this so? Subhūti, the heap of merit accumulated by a bodhisattva who practices generosity without abiding is immeasurable.Subhūti, what do you think? Is it easy to measure the extent of space in the eastern direction?Subhūti replied, \"No, Blessed One, that is not so.\The Blessed One said: \"Subhūti, similarly, is it easy to measure the extent of space in the southern, western, northern directions, in the regions above and below, in the intermediate directions—throughout all ten directions?\Subhūti replied, \"Blessed One, that is not so.\The Blessed One said, \"Subhūti, likewise, when a bodhisattva practices generosity without abiding in anything whatsoever, the resulting heap of merit is immeasurable. Indeed, Subhūti, the extent of such merit cannot be easily grasped.\What do you think, Subhūti? Should the Tathāgata be viewed through perfect marks?Subhūti replied, \"No, Blessed One, that is not so.\One should not view the Tathāgata through his perfect marks indeed.Why is that? Because what the Tathāgata has taught as \"perfect marks\" are themselves not truly existent perfect marks.When he had spoken thus, the Blessed One addressed the Venerable Subhūti with these words:Subhūti, to the extent that perfect marks appear, to that same extent they are false.[When contemplating the Tathāgata,] to the extent that perfect marks have non-existence, to that extent there is no falsity in their conventional appearance.Thus, the Tathāgata should be viewed as being without marks and without characteristic non-existence.When the Blessed One had spoken these words, the Venerable Subhūti addressed the Blessed One with these words:Blessed One, in the future time, during the final phase of the five-hundred-year period when the sacred Dharma is being utterly destroyed, will there arise any sentient beings who will generate correct perception regarding such sūtra teachings being explained?The Blessed One said, \"Subhūti, do not say as you have just expressed: 'In the future time, during the final phase of the five-hundred-year period when the sacred Dharma is thoroughly deteriorating, will there be sentient beings who will generate correct perception upon hearing the words of sūtras such as this?' You should not harbor such doubt.\Subhūti, in the future time, during the final phase of the five-hundred-year period when the sacred Dharma will be completely destroyed, bodhisattva great beings will emerge who are endowed with discipline, endowed with qualities, and endowed with wisdom.Subhūti, those bodhisattva great beings have not attended upon and served just one Buddha alone.They have not generated roots of virtue with just a single Buddha, but rather with many hundreds of thousands of Buddhas.Furthermore, Subhūti, those bodhisattva great beings who have venerated and served many hundreds of thousands of Buddhas, and who have generated roots of virtue with many hundreds of thousands of Buddhas, will arise.Subhūti, those who will generate even a single moment of faith when this sūtra teachings are explained are known to the Tathāgata.Subhūti, those future practitioners—who possess moral discipline and wisdom, honor many Buddhas, and are free from distorted perceptions of self—are both seen and fully known by the Tathāgata with his Buddha-eye.Subhūti, all those sentient beings will generate and accumulate immeasurable heaps of merit.Why is that? Because, Subhūti, those bodhisattva great beings do not engage in perceptions that grasp at a self, a sentient being, a life-force, or a person.There is no perception of sentient beings, no perception of life-force, and no engagement in the perception of persons; for this reason.Subhūti, those bodhisattva great beings do not entertain the perception of dharma, nor do they engage in the perception of non-phenomena.Nor do they do not engage in even without perception.Why is that? Subhūti, if those bodhisattvas, great beings, were to engage in the perception of dharma, that itself would become their grasping at a self.For they will engage in grasping at the concept of sentient beings, grasping at the concept of life-force, and grasping at the concept of person.If they were to engage with the perception that dharmas lack a self, even that very perception would become a form of self-grasping.Because this would lead to grasping at sentient beings as inherently real, grasping to the notion of a life-force, and grasping to the concept of person.Why is that? Subhūti, a bodhisattva-mahasattva should neither grasp at dharma through wrong conceptualization nor grasp at non-dharma—this is to remain free from both extremes.Therefore, with this intention in mind, the Tathāgata taught: \"Those who understand this discourse on Dharma to be like a raft should abandon even phenomena, let alone non-dharmas.\Furthermore, the Blessed One spoke thus to Venerable Subhūti with these words:Subhūti, what do you think?Is there any dharma that the Tathāgata has fully and completely awakened to as unsurpassed, perfect, complete enlightenment?Do you think there is any dharma that the Tathāgata has actually taught?When the Blessed One had spoken these words, Venerable Subhūti addressed the Blessed One with these words:Blessed One, according to my understanding of what the Blessed One has taught, there is no dharma whatsoever through which the Tathāgata has fully and completely awakened to unsurpassed, perfect, complete enlightenment, indeed.There is no dharma whatsoever that has been taught by the Tathāgata indeed.Why is that? Whatever dharma the Tathāgata has fully and completely awakened to or whatever dharma he has taught—these do not exist to be grasped and do not exist to be expressed.That is neither dharma nor not truly existent; this is the reason why.Why is that? Because noble persons are distinguished by their realization of the unconditioned.The Blessed One said, \"What do you think, Subhūti?\O Subhuti, what do you think? If any son or daughter of noble family were to fill this great trichiliocosm with the seven kinds of precious substances and offer it all as a gift, would that son or daughter of noble family generate a numerous heap of merit on that basis?Subhūti replied, \"Blessed One, it is numerous indeed.\There are numerous Sugatas, indeed.From that basis of engaging with the profound teachings on emptiness, bodhisattvas—those sons or daughters of noble family—generate a numerous heap of merit.Why is that? Because that very heap of merit is itself not truly existent.Therefore, the Tathāgata taught of \"heap of merit, heap of merit.\The Blessed One said: \"Subhūti, suppose a son or daughter of noble family were to fill this entire great trichiliocosm with the seven kinds of precious substances and offer it all as a gift. Now compare this with someone else who would take up even a single four-line verse from this discourse on Dharma, memorize it, explain it to others, and correctly explain in detail its meaning. This second person would generate a vastly superior heap of merit—merit that is immeasurable and incalculable.\Why is that? Subhūti, it is because the unsurpassed, perfect, complete enlightenment of all the Tathāgatas, Arhats, and Perfectly Enlightened Buddhas arises from this.Therefore, even the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, are born from this.Why is this so? Subhūti, what are called 'Buddha's phenomena, Buddha's phenomena' - the Tathāgata has taught that these Buddha dharmas do not exist. That is precisely why they are called 'Buddha's phenomena.'Therefore, they are called Buddha phenomena.Subhūti, what do you think?Does a Stream-enterer think, \"self have attained the fruit of stream-entry\" in this mind?Subhūti replied, \"No, Blessed One, that is not so.\Why is that? Because, Blessed One, he has not entered into anything and is not truly existent.Therefore, it is called a \"Stream-enterer.\He has not entered into form, nor into sound, nor into smell, nor into taste, nor into tactile sensation, nor into phenomena whatsoever.Therefore, it is called \"Stream-enterer.\Why is that? Blessed One, if a Stream-enterer were to think, 'I have attained the fruit of Stream-Entry,' this very thought would constitute grasping at a self indeed.One grasps at [the concept of] sentient beings, grasps at [the concept of] life-force, and grasps at [the concept of] persons, indeed.The Blessed One said, \"Subhūti, what do you think?\Does a Once-Returner think to themselves, 'This self has attained the fruit of a Once-Returner'?Subhūti replied, \"No, Blessed One, that is not so.\Why is that? Because there is no dharma whatsoever of having entered into the state of being a Once-Returner that is not truly existent.Therefore, it is called a \"Once-Returner.\Blessed One, if a Once-Returner thinks, 'I have attained the fruit of Once-Return,' that very thought would constitute grasping at a self indeed.One would fall into the error of grasping on sentient beings, clinging to the concept of a life-force, and maintaining the notion of a truly existent person, indeed.The Blessed One said, \"What do you think, Subhūti?\Does a Non-returner think, \"This self has attained the fruit of Non-returning\" in the mind?Subhūti replied, \"Blessed One, that is not so.\Why is that? Because there is no dharma whatsoever that has entered into the state of non-returning anāgāmin.Therefore, it is called a Non-returner.The Blessed One said, \"Subhūti, what do you think about this?\Does an Arhat think to themselves, 'self have attained Arhatship'?Subhūti replied, \"No, Blessed One, that is not so.\Why is that? Because there is no dharma whatsoever that should be called 'Arhat' that is not truly existent.Blessed One, if an Arhat were to think, 'I have attained Arhatship,' that very thought would constitute grasping at a self, indeed.One grasps at the notion of sentient beings, grasps at the concept of life-force, and grasps at the idea of person, indeed.Blessed One, I have been taught by the Tathāgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened Buddha to be foremost among those who dwell free from afflictions.Blessed One, although I am indeed an Arhat free from attachment, I do not harbor the thought, 'I am an Arhat.'Blessed One, if I were to think, 'I have attained Arhatship,' then the Tathāgata would still declare me to be 'Subhūti, son of noble family, the foremost among those who dwell free from afflictions.'Because I abide without abiding anywhere whatsoever, the Buddha does not prophesy about me as 'one who dwells free from afflictions,' indeed.The Blessed One said, \"Subhūti, what do you think?\Do you think there is any dharma whatsoever that the Tathāgata obtained from the Tathāgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened Buddha Dipankara?Subhūti replied, \"No, Blessed One, that is not so.\There is not a single dharma that the Tathāgata has truly obtained from the Tathāgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened Buddha Dipankara, indeed.The Blessed One said, \"Subhūti, if any bodhisattva should declare, 'I will bring about the arrays of buddha-fields,' they speak falsely.\Why is this so? Subhūti, the arrays of buddha-fields that are called \"arrays of buddha-fields\"—the Tathāgata has taught that these arrays do not have non-existence.Therefore, these are called \"the arrays of buddha-fields.\Therefore, Subhūti, the bodhisattva, the great being, should generate a mind without abiding this:One should generate bodhicitta without abiding in anything whatsoever.One should generate bodhicitta without abiding in form.One should generate bodhicitta without abiding in sound, smell, taste, tactile sensation, or dharma.Subhūti, consider this example: If a person's body were to become enormous—as vast as Mount Sumeru, the king of mountains. What do you think, Subhūti? Would such a body truly be great?Subhūti replied, \"Blessed One, that body is indeed great.\The Sugata taught that such a great body, indeed.Why is that? Because the Tathāgata has taught it as lacking inherent existence.Therefore, it is called that body is 'great.'That which is lacking inherent existence, therefore it is called a 'body.'The Blessed One said, \"What do you think, Subhūti?\Subhūti, what do you think? If there were as many Ganges Rivers as there are grains of sand in the great Ganges River, would the grains of sand contained in all of those rivers be numerous?Subhūti replied, \"Blessed One, even those Ganges Rivers themselves are numerous, what need is there to mention the grains of sand in those Ganges Rivers?\The Blessed One said, \"Subhūti, you should have conviction.\You should thoroughly understand this, one should.If someone, whether man or woman, were to fill as many world-systems as there are grains of sand in those Ganges Rivers with the seven kinds of precious substances...If one were to practice generosity to the Tathāgatas, Arhats, and Perfectly Enlightened Buddhas, what do you think, Subhūti? Would that man or woman generate numerous merit from that basis?Subhūti replied, \"Blessed One, it is numerous indeed.\There are numerous Sugatas indeed.Whether man or woman, from this basis one will generate numerous and incalculable mass of merit indeed.The Blessed One said: \"Subhūti, if someone were to fill as many world realms as exist with the seven kinds of precious substances...\Compared to making generosity to the Tathāgatas, Arhats, and Perfectly Enlightened Buddhas, if a noble person takes up even a single four-line verse from this discourse on Dharma, thoroughly explains it, and correctly teaches it to others, they will generate far greater merit—immeasurable and incalculable—from this basis alone.Furthermore, Subhūti, any place where even a four-line verse from this discourse on Dharma is recited or taught becomes a sacred shrine for the world with its gods, humans, and asuras—like a stupa embodying the Dharmakaya of the Buddha. How much more marvelous, then, are those who will take up this entire discourse on Dharma, write down it, grasp it in memory, hold the physical text, recite it aloud, thoroughly comprehend its meaning through the wisdom of hearing, and meditate upon it without error! Such practitioners will be endowed with the most extraordinary wonder, for wherever this profound teaching is properly practiced, the Buddha himself abides, along with noble beings such as Mañjuśrī and various bodhisattvas.In that place, the teach himself dwells, as do other venerable spiritual masters.When the Blessed One had spoken these words, the Venerable Subhūti addressed the Blessed One, saying:Blessed One, what is the name of this discourse on Dharma?How should I uphold this?When he had spoken thus, the Blessed One spoke thus to the Venerable Subhūti with these words:Subhūti, this discourse on Dharma is called 'The Perfection of Wisdom.'Hold this thus.Why is this so? Subhūti, that very Perfection of Wisdom which the Tathāgata has taught is itself not a Perfection; this is because...Therefore, it is called the Perfection of Wisdom.Subhūti, what do you think?Do you think there is any dharma that has been taught by the Tathāgata?Subhūti replied, \"Blessed One, whatever dharmas the Tathāgata has taught, none of them does not exist indeed.\The Blessed One said, \"Subhūti, what do you think?\Would you consider the particles of earth throughout the great trichiliocosm to be numerous?Subhūti replied, \"Blessed One, those particles of earth are indeed numerous.\There are numerous Sugatas, indeed.Why is that? Because what the Blessed One has taught as particles of earth, the Tathāgata has taught as not truly existent. That is why they are called particles of earth.Therefore, it is called 'particles of earth.'Whatever world-systems exist, the Tathāgata has taught them to be not truly existent. Therefore, they are called world-systems.Therefore, it is called a \"world-system.\The Blessed One said, \"What do you think, Subhūti?\Do you think the Tathāgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened Buddha should be viewed through the thirty-two marks of a great being?Subhūti replied, \"No, Blessed One, that is not so.\Why is that? Because the thirty-two marks of a great being that the Tathāgata has taught are actually taught by the Tathāgata to be not truly existent characteristics. That is why they are called 'the thirty-two marks of a great being.'Therefore, it is called the thirty-two marks of a great being.The Blessed One said: \"Subhūti, if any man or woman were to completely give up bodies as numerous as the grains of sand of the Ganges River, and furthermore, if someone were to take up just a four-line verse from this discourse on Dharma and correctly teach it to others, this latter person would, from that basis, generate far more merit—immeasurable and incalculable.\Then the Venerable Subhūti shed tears due to the force of the dharma.Then Elder Subhuti, overwhelmed by his recognition of the profound teaching on emptiness, wiped away his tears and addressed the Blessed One with these words:This discourse on Dharma has been taught by as many Tathāgatas as have ever existed. O Blessed One, how wondrous indeed! O Sugata, how wondrous indeed!Blessed One, since wisdom arose in self, self has never before heard such a discourse on Dharma indeed.Why is that? The Blessed One, those sentient beings who will generate correct perception when this sūtra is explained will be endowed with extraordinary wonder indeed.Why is that? Blessed One, what is termed correct perception is itself not truly existent perception.Therefore, the Tathāgata taught: \"This is what is called 'correct perception.'\Blessed One, it is not amazing to me that I comprehend and have conviction in this discourse on Dharma that you have taught.Blessed One, in the latter days, in the final era, during the final phase of the five-hundred-year period, those sentient beings who will take up this discourse on Dharma, who will write down, grasp, hold, recite, and thoroughly comprehend its meaning—they will be endowed with extraordinary wonder, indeed.Moreover, Blessed One, they will not engage in any perception of self.They will not engage in the perception of sentient beings, the perception of life-force, or the perception of persons indeed.Why is that? Because, Blessed One, what is perceived as self, perceived as sentient being, perceived as life-force, and perceived as person—these very perceptions are free from all perceptions.Why is that? Because the Buddha Blessed Ones are free from all perceptions.When he had spoken thus, the Blessed One said to Venerable Subhūti with these words:Subhūti, it is so. It is exactly so.Truly remarkable will be those sentient beings who, when hearing this sūtra explained, neither flinch nor become anxious, nor fall into fear. They will be endowed with the most extraordinary wonder.Why is that? Subhūti, this supreme Perfection of wisdom has been taught by the Tathāgata.Those supreme Perfections that the Tathāgata taught are likewise taught by immeasurable, immeasurable Blessed One Buddhas; therefore...Therefore, it is called the supreme Perfection.Moreover, Subhūti, what is called the Tathāgata's perfection of patience is not a perfection at all.Why is that? Subhūti, when the King of Kalinga cut off my limbs and extremities, at that time I had no perception of a self, no perception of a sentient being, no perception of a life-force, nor any perception of a person.I had no perception whatsoever of a self, yet it was not the case that I was without perception.Why is that? Subhūti, had I harbored any perception of a self at that time, then perceptions of ill-will would have arisen in me as well.When the perception of sentient beings, the perception of life-force, and the perception of persons arise, then at that time the perception of ill-will also inevitably arises as a consequence.Subhūti, through my supernormal knowledge, I know that in the past I existed as a sage ṛṣi called 'The Preacher of Patience' for five hundred lifetimes. Even then, I had no perception of a self ātma-saṃjñā.There arose no perception of sentient being, no perception of life-force, and no perception of person.Therefore, Subhūti, the bodhisattva great being, having abandoned all perception,One should generate bodhicitta toward unsurpassed, perfect, complete enlightenment.One should generate bodhicitta without abiding in form.One should generate bodhicitta without abiding in sound, smell, taste, or tactile sensation.One should generate bodhicitta without abiding even in dharma.One should generate bodhicitta without abiding in non-phenomena.One should generate bodhicitta without abiding in anything whatsoever.Why is that? Because that which abides is itself without abiding.Therefore, the Tathāgata taught: \"A bodhisattva should practice generosity without abiding anywhere.\Furthermore, Subhūti, a bodhisattva should this kind of complete generosity for the benefit of all sentient beings.That which is the perception of sentient beings is itself without perception.Those very sentient beings whom the Tathāgata taught as 'all sentient beings' do not actually exist.Why is that? Subhūti, the Tathāgata speaks what is authentic, speaks what is true, and speaks in accordance with the nature of reality.The Tathāgata does not speak falsely, for he perceives the true nature of all phenomena.Furthermore, Subhūti, in whatever dharma the Tathāgata has fully and completely awakened to or taught, there is neither truth nor falsehood.Subhūti, consider this: Just as a person with eyes who enters darkness sees nothing at all, in the same way should be viewed a bodhisattva who completely gives up generosity while clinging to the notion of inherent existence.Furthermore, Subhūti, consider this: When dawn breaks and the sun rises, a person with eyes sees a multitude of forms. In the same way, you should view a bodhisattva who completely gives up generosity without falling into the reification of things.Furthermore, Subhūti, those sons or daughters of noble family who take up this discourse on Dharma, grasping it, hold it, recite it, thoroughly master it, and correctly explain in detail to others—they are known by the Tathāgata. They are seen by the Tathāgata.Subhūti, all those sentient beings shall generate immeasurable heaps of merit.Furthermore, Subhūti, if a man or woman were to completely give up as many bodies as there are grains of sand in the Ganges River in the morning time, and likewise at midday were to completely give up as many bodies as there are grains of sand in the Ganges River, and again in the evening were to completely give up the same number of bodies; if they were to continue completely giving up their bodies in this discourse on Dharma for inconceivably many billions and trillions of kalpas than...If someone, having heard this discourse on Dharma, does not reject it, they will generate numerous, immeasurable and incalculable merit from this basis alone. What need is there to speak of the merit gained by one who writes it down, takes it up, grasps it, holds it, recites it, thoroughly masters it, and correctly explains it in detail extensively to others?Furthermore, Subhūti, this discourse on Dharma is inconceivable and incomparable.One should understand that the ripening effect of this is likewise inconceivable.The Tathāgata has taught this discourse on Dharma for the benefit of sentient beings who have genuinely entered the supreme vehicle, and for the sake of those who have authentically embarked upon the most excellent vehicle.Those who take up this discourse on Dharma, grasping it, hold it, recite it, thoroughly master it, and correctly explain in detail to others—they are known by the Tathāgata; they are seen by the Tathāgata.All these sentient beings will be endowed with immeasurable heaps of merit.They will be endowed with heaps of merit that are inconceivable, incomparable, immeasurable, and immeasurable.All those sentient beings will carry my enlightenment upon their shoulders.Why is this so? Subhūti, those with conviction toward inferior aspirations are unable to listen to this discourse on Dharma.Not by those who hold the view of self; not by those who hold the view of sentient beings; not by those who hold the view of a life-force.Those who hold the view of person cannot listen to, take up, retain, read, or thoroughly master these profound teachings.This is because there is non-existence of basis for it.Furthermore, Subhūti, that place where this sūtra is taught will become worthy of veneration, respect, and circumambulation by the world, including its gods, humans, and asuras.That place shall become a sacred ground, worthy of prostration and circumambulation.That place becomes like a sacred shrine.Furthermore, Subhūti, those sons of noble family or daughters of noble family who take up, grasping, hold, recite, and thoroughly comprehend such words of this sūtra will experience purifying trials—their negative karma will be thoroughly exhausted in this very life.They will be thoroughly tormented-taste.Why is this so? Subhūti, those sentient beings who have committed negative actions in previous lives that would lead to rebirth in lower realms will experience the ripening of those actions through suffering in this very life, and through this suffering, those negative actions from previous lives that would have caused rebirth in the lower realms will be purified.One will also attain the enlightenment of a Buddha.Subhūti, with my supernormal knowledge, I perceive that in the distant past—immeasurable eons ago and even far beyond those immeasurable eons—long before the appearance of Dipankara, the Tathāgata, Arhat, and Perfectly Enlightened Buddha, and indeed vastly preceding his time, there appeared eighty-four hundred thousand million billion Buddhas. I pleased and served all of them.Having pleased them, I did not cause them displeasure nor did I disappoint their exalted minds.Subhūti, those Buddhas, those Blessed Ones, whom I pleased and served and never disappointed, and those who, in the final phase of the five-hundred-year period, will take up this sūtra, write it down, hold it, grasping it, recite it, and thoroughly master it—Subhūti, compared to this latter heap of merit, the former heap of merit does not approach even a hundredth part of it.It cannot be compared to even a thousandth part or a hundred-thousandth part. It transcends all calculation by number, determination by measure, and quantification by counting. No example can illustrate it, no equivalent can match it, and nothing can serve as its causal basis. It stands beyond all comparison whatsoever.Subhūti, at that time, if I were to describe the heap of merit that would be accumulated by those sons or daughters of noble family who receive and retain this teaching—the heap of merit of those sons or daughters of noble family—sentient beings would become bewildered and their minds would become utterly confused.Furthermore, Subhūti, this discourse on Dharma is inconceivable—beyond ordinary understanding—and its ripening effects will likewise be inconceivably profound and immeasurable.The ripening effect of this should be understood as truly inconceivable.Then, the Venerable Subhūti addressed the Blessed One with these words:Blessed One, how should those who have genuinely entered the bodhisattva vehicle abide?How should one practice?How should one firmly hold the mind?When he had spoken thus, the Blessed One spoke thus to the Venerable Subhūti with these words:Subhūti, in this case, one who has genuinely entered the bodhisattva vehicle thinks, 'I shall lead all sentient beings to complete nirvana in the realm beyond suffering where no aggregates remain,' yet while bringing beings to completely pass beyond suffering, no being whatsoever is actually brought to nirvana.Thus, although immeasurable sentient beings have been guided beyond suffering into nirvana, one should generate bodhicitta that not a single sentient being has actually been led to liberation.Why is that? Subhūti, if a bodhisattva maintains the perception of sentient beings as truly existent, they cannot be called a bodhisattva.Even if one maintains the perception of persons, for this very reason, one cannot be called a bodhisattva.Why is that? Subhūti, it is because there is no dharma whatsoever that can be called \"one who has genuinely entered the bodhisattva vehicle.\Subhūti, What do you think?Does the Tathāgata think there is any dharma by which the Tathāgata has fully and completely awakened to unsurpassed, perfect, complete enlightenment through the Tathāgata Dipankara?When the Blessed One had spoken these words, Venerable Subhūti, who was endowed with long life, addressed the Blessed One with these words:The Blessed One, the Tathāgata, did not attain any dharma whatsoever of unsurpassed, perfect, complete enlightenment from the Tathāgata Dipankara.When he had spoken thus, the Blessed One spoke thus to Venerable Subhūti with these words.Subhūti, it is so. It is exactly so.The Tathāgata did not receive any dharma whatsoever from the Tathāgata Dipankara by which he fully and completely awakened to unsurpassed, perfect, complete enlightenment.Subhūti, if there were any dharma that the Tathāgata had truly attained in fully and completely awakened, then the Tathāgata Dipankara would never have prophesied to me, saying, 'Young brahmin, in the future time you will become a Tathāgata, an Arhat, a Perfectly Enlightened Buddha named Shakyamuni.'Subhūti, in this way, there is no dharma whatsoever through which the Tathāgata has fully and completely awakened to unsurpassed, perfect, complete enlightenment.Therefore, the Tathāgata Dipankara prophesied to me, saying: 'Young brahmin, in the future time, you will become the Tathāgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened Buddha known as Shakyamuni.'Why is this so? Subhūti, the term 'Tathāgata' is a designation for true suchness.Furthermore, Subhūti, should anyone claim, \"The Tathāgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened Buddha has fully and completely awakened to unsurpassed, perfect, complete enlightenment,\" they would be speaking falsely.It is exactly so, the Tathāgata speaks of \"bodhisattva, bodhisattva\Why is that? Subhūti, it is because there is no dharma whatsoever that the Tathāgata has fully and completely awakened to in unsurpassed, perfect, complete enlightenment.Subhūti, in the dharmas through which the Tathāgata has become fully and completely awakened or which he has taught, there is neither truth nor falsehood.Therefore, the Tathāgata has taught that all dharmas are Buddha dharmas.Subhūti, what we call 'all dharmas' are actually non-phenomena; that is why they are called 'all dharmas.'Therefore, all phenomena are called Buddha dharmas.Subhūti, this is like this: imagine a person possessing a human body who transforms into a great body.The Venerable Subhūti replied, \"Blessed One, what the Tathāgata has taught as 'a person possessing a human body' and having 'a great body,' the Tathāgata has also taught as not truly existent.\Thus it is, Subhūti. Therefore, it is called possessing a body on the conventional level while having a great body that transcends ordinary conceptualization—one that, through the wisdom of equanimity, embraces all sentient beings without seeing them as inherently existent.The Blessed One said: 'Subhūti, it is so. It is precisely so.'If a bodhisattva declares, \"I will lead all sentient beings to completely pass beyond suffering,\" they should not be called a bodhisattva.Why is that? Subhūti, do you think there is any dharma whatsoever that can be called a 'bodhisattva'?Subhūti replied, \"No, Blessed One, that is not so.\The Blessed One said, \"Therefore, Subhūti, the Tathāgata has taught that all dharmas are devoid of sentient beings, devoid of life-force, and devoid of persons.\Furthermore, Subhūti, if any bodhisattva should say, \"I will accomplish the arrays of buddha-fields,\" they too should be understood in the same manner.Why is that? Subhūti, the arrays of buddha-fields that are called \"arrays of buddha-fields\" - the Tathāgata has taught that these have no non-existence. Therefore, they are called \"arrays of buddha-fields.\Therefore, these are is called \"the arrays of buddha-fields.\The Blessed One said: \"What do you think, Subhūti? Does the Tathāgata possess the fleshly eye?\Subhūti, what do you think? Does the Tathāgata possess the eye of flesh?Subhūti replied, \"Yes, Blessed One, it is indeed so. The Tathāgata possesses the eye of flesh.\The Blessed One said, \"Subhūti, what do you think?\Do you think the Tathāgata possesses the divine eye?Subhūti replied, \"Yes, Blessed One, it is indeed so. The Tathāgata possesses the divine eye.\The Blessed One said, \"Subhūti, what do you think?\Do you think the Tathāgata possesses the eye of wisdom?Subhūti replied, \"Yes, Blessed One, it is indeed so.\The Tathāgata possesses the eye of wisdom.The Blessed One said, \"Subhūti, what do you think?\Do you think that the Tathāgata possesses the Dharma eye?Subhūti replied, \"Yes, Blessed One, it is indeed so.\The Tathāgata possesses the Dharma eye.The Blessed One said, \"Subhūti, what do you think?\Subhūti said, \"Indeed so, Bhagavan. Do you think the Tathāgata possesses the Buddha eye?\Subhūti replied, \"Yes, Blessed One, it is indeed so.\The Tathāgata possesses the Buddha eye.The Blessed One said, \"Subhūti, what do you think?\What do you think, Subhūti? If there were as many Ganges rivers as there are grains of sand in the Ganges River, and if there were as many world-systems as there are grains of sand in all those Ganges rivers, would those world-systems be numerous?Subhūti replied, \"Blessed One, Yes, Blessed One, it is indeed so.\Those world-systems are numerous indeed.The Blessed One said, \"Subhūti, I completely know the diverse mental continuums in the minds of all sentient beings throughout these world-systems.\Why is that? Subhūti, what is called 'mental continuum, mental continuum' has been taught by the Tathāgata to be without non-existence. Therefore...Therefore, this is called the mental continuum.Why is that? Subhūti, because even the past mind cannot be apprehended.The future mind, too, cannot be apprehended.Because even the present mind cannot be apprehended.What do you think, Subhūti?If someone were to fill this entire great trichiliocosm with the seven kinds of precious substances and offer it as generosity, would that son or daughter of noble family generate numerous merit from this act?Subhūti replied, \"Blessed One, it is indeed numerous.\There are indeed numerous Sugatas.The Blessed One said, \"Subhūti, it is so. It is exactly so.\Through this basis, son or daughter of noble family generate numerous heaps of merit.Furthermore, Subhūti, if a heap of merit were truly a heap of merit in itself, the Tathāgata would not have spoken of a 'heap of merit' as a 'heap of merit.'Subhūti, what do you think of this?Do you think that one should view the Tathāgata through the perfect accomplishment of the Form Body?Subhūti replied, \"No, Blessed One, that is not so.\One should not view the Tathāgata as being defined by the perfect accomplishment of the Form Body indeed.Why is that?

Because, Blessed One, what is called 'the perfect accomplishment of the Form Body' has been taught by the Tathāgata as being not truly existent.Therefore, it is called the perfect accomplishment of the Form Body.The Blessed One said, \"Subhūti, what do you think?\Do you think that the Tathāgata should be viewed through his perfect marks?Subhūti replied, \"No, Blessed One, that is not so.\One should not view the Tathāgata through his perfect marks, indeed.Why is that? Because the perfect marks of which the Tathāgata has taught are not truly existent perfect marks. That is why the Tathāgata taught of them as \"perfect marks.\Therefore, it is called \"perfect marks.\The Blessed One said, \"Subhūti, what do you think?\Do you suppose that the Tathāgata thinks, 'I have taught the dharma'? Subhūti, you should not see it this way.For there is no dharma whatsoever that has been taught by the Tathāgata.The Blessed One said, \"Subhūti, whoever would say, 'The Tathāgata teaches the dharma'—such a person would be speaking falsely. Subhūti, that person would be misrepresenting me by grasping at what does not exist.\Why is this so? Subhūti, what we call \"teaching the dharma\"—there is actually no dharma whatsoever that can be apprehended as \"teaching the dharma.\Then, the Venerable Subhūti addressed the Blessed One with these words:Blessed One, in the future time, will there be sentient beings who, upon hearing this dharma explained, will generate genuine faith?The Blessed One said, \"Subhūti, they are neither sentient beings nor are they devoid of sentient beings.\Why is that? Subhūti, regarding what are called 'sentient beings,' the Tathāgata has taught that they are devoid of sentient beings.Therefore, they are called \"sentient beings.\Subhūti, what do you think?The Tathāgata said to Subhūti, \"What do you think? Is there any dharma whatsoever that the Tathāgata has fully and completely awakened to in unsurpassed, perfect, complete enlightenment?\The Venerable Subhūti replied, \"Blessed One, there is no dharma whatsoever that the Tathāgata has fully and completely awakened to as the unsurpassed, perfect, complete enlightenment.\The Blessed One said, \"Subhūti, it is so. It is exactly so.\In enlightenment, not even the subtlest dharma can be found or perceived.Therefore, it is called unsurpassed, perfect, complete enlightenment.Furthermore, Subhūti, that dharma is equal; in it there is no inequality.In this enlightened state, there exists neither inequality nor equal whatsoever, as all phenomena are realized to be empty of inherent non-existence. Therefore, through the complete abandonment of self-grasping and its latent tendencies, it is called unsurpassed, perfect, complete enlightenment.That unsurpassed, perfect, complete enlightenment is equal in its selflessness, being devoid of sentient beings, being devoid of life-force, and being devoid of persons.Through all virtuous dharmas, one becomes fully and completely awakened.Subhūti, what are called 'virtuous dharmas'—the Tathāgata has taught that they are non-phenomena.Therefore, these are called virtuous dharmas.Furthermore, Subhūti, if any son or daughter of noble family were to gather as many heaps of the seven kinds of precious substances as there are Mount Sumeru, the king of mountains, throughout this great trichiliocosm world-system and offer them as gifts—and if, on the other hand, anyone were to take up from this Perfection of Wisdom even just a single four-line verse, memorize it, and then teach it to others—Subhūti, the former heap of merit would not approach even a hundredth part of the latter, nor could it even serve as a basis for comparison. The difference between them is beyond measure.Subhūti, what do you think?If one thinks that the Tathāgata thinks, \"I have liberated sentient beings,\" Subhūti, it should not be viewed this way.Why is that? Because, Subhūti, there are no sentient beings whatsoever who have been liberated by the Tathāgata.Subhūti, if the Tathāgata were to liberate any sentient being whatsoever, this itself would constitute the Tathāgata's grasping at a self.This would constitute grasping at the concept of sentient being, grasping at the concept of life-force, and grasping at the concept of person.Subhūti, what we call 'grasping at a self' has been taught by the Tathāgata as non-existence of grasping. Yet this very teaching is what childish ordinary beings take up.Subhūti, those called 'childish ordinary beings' have been taught by the Tathāgata to be non-existence at all.Therefore, they are called \"childish ordinary beings.\Subhūti, what do you think?Do you think that the Tathāgata should be viewed through his perfect marks?Subhūti replied, \"Blessed One, that is not so.\One should not view the Tathāgata by the perfect marks, indeed.The Blessed One said, \"Subhūti, it is so. It is exactly so.The Tathāgata should not be viewed through his perfect marks.Subhūti, why is this so? If one were to view the Tathāgata through the perfect marks, then a wheel-turning monarch would also be a Tathāgata.Therefore, one should not view the Tathāgata through the perfect marks.Then the Venerable Subhūti addressed the Blessed One with these words:Blessed One, as I understand the meaning of what you have taught: The Tathāgata should not be viewed through the perfect marks indeed.Then, at that time, the Blessed One spoke thus these verses:Those who see me in form,
Those who know me through sound—
They have entered a mistaken path.Those people do not see me.Buddhas should be seen as the dharmatā.The Guides are the dharma-kāya itself;
Since dharmatā cannot be known,
It cannot be cognized by consciousness.What do you think, Subhūti?If you believe that the Tathāgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Complete Buddha attained fully and completely awakened through his perfect marks, then Subhūti, you should not view it this way.Subhūti, the Tathāgata has not attained unsurpassed, perfect enlightenment through possessing perfect marks.Subhūti, you should not think that those who have genuinely entered the bodhisattva vehicle have designated any dharma as destroyed or designated as annihilated. Subhūti, this should not be viewed in such a way.Those who have genuinely entered the bodhisattva vehicle neither destroy any dharma nor designate anything as annihilated.Furthermore, Subhūti, if a son or daughter of noble family were to fill as many world-systems as there are grains of sand in the Ganges River with the seven kinds of precious substances and offer them as acts of generosity, compared to a bodhisattva who attains patience regarding the non-existence of self and non-arising nature of phenomena based on this discourse on Dharma—such a bodhisattva would generate a far greater heap of merit, numerous, immeasurable and incalculable.Furthermore, Subhūti, a bodhisattva should not grasp at a heap of merit.Venerable Subhūti replied, \"Blessed One, should a bodhisattva not grasp at a heap of merit?\The Blessed One said, \"Subhūti, merit should indeed be fully take up, but not wrongly take up.\Therefore, it is called \"that which is to be appropriated\" [in the correct way].Furthermore, Subhūti, if anyone should say, \"The Tathāgata comes or goes, stands or sits, or lies down to sleep\"—such a person, Subhūti, has not understood the meaning of my teaching.Why is this so? Subhūti, the one who is called \"Tathāgata\" is so named because he neither goes anywhere nor comes from anywhere.Therefore, he is called the Tathāgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened Buddha.Furthermore, Subhūti, suppose a son or daughter of noble family were to take all the particles of earth contained within this great trichiliocosm—all the countless specks of dust in a billion world-systems—and grind them into the finest possible powder, until each particle was reduced to its subtlest subtle particles. What do you think, Subhūti? Would that collection of subtle particles be numerous?Subhūti replied, \"Blessed One, Yes, Blessed One, it is indeed so.\That collection of subtle particles is indeed numerous.Why is that? Because, Blessed One, if there were truly such a thing as a collection of subtle particles, the Blessed One would not have called it \"a collection of subtle particles.\Why is that? What the Blessed One has taught as \"a collection of subtle particles\" has been taught by the Tathāgata as \"not truly existent.\Therefore, it is called \"a collection of subtle particles.\That which the Tathāgata has taught as \"the great trichiliocosm\"—the Tathāgata has taught that it is not truly existent as a realm.Therefore, it is called \"the great trichiliocosm\Why is that? Blessed One, if there were a world-system, it would be grasped at a totality.What the Tathāgata has taught as 'grasping at a totality' has been taught by the Tathāgata as ultimately being not truly existent grasping at all. That is precisely why it is conventionally taught as 'grasping at a totality.'Therefore, it is called \"grasping at a totality.\The Blessed One said, \"Subhūti, grasping at a totality is merely conventional.\That dharma is non-existence,
Yet it is grasped by childish ordinary beings.Subhūti, what is the reason for this? If someone were to claim, \"The Tathāgata taught a view of self\"...If someone were to claim, \"The Tathāgata has taught the view of sentient beings, the view of a life-force, and the view of persons,\" would such a person be speaking correctly?Subhūti replied, \"No, Blessed One, that is not so.\No, that is not so regarding the Sugata.Why is that? Because what the Blessed One, the Tathāgata, has taught as the \"view of self\" has been taught by the Tathāgata as \"not truly existent.\" Therefore...Therefore, it is called \"the view of self.\The Blessed One said: \"Subhūti, in this way, one who has genuinely entered the bodhisattva vehicle should know all dharma, should view all dharma, and should have conviction of all dharma.\Thus, one should understand in such a way that one is without abiding in the perception of dharma.Why is that? Subhūti, what is called 'perception of dharma, perception of dharma'—the Tathāgata has taught that to be without perception. Therefore...Therefore, it is called \"perception of dharma, perception of dharma.\Furthermore, Subhūti, if a bodhisattva, great being were to fill immeasurable and countless world-systems with the seven kinds of precious substances and offer these as gifts, and if a son or daughter of noble family were to write down even a four-line verse from this Perfection of Wisdom, memorize it, hold it, read it, thoroughly master it, and correctly explain in detail to others, this latter action would generate a far greater mass of merit—immeasurable and incalculable.\"How should one correctly explain in detail?\" one might ask. One correctly explains in detail precisely in the same way that one does not correctly explain in detail.Therefore, it is called correctly explain in detail.Like stars, visual distortions, and lamps,
Like illusions, dewdrops, and bubbles,
Like dreams, lightning, and clouds—
View all conditioned phenomena in this way.When the Blessed One had finished speaking these words, the venerable elder Subhūti, along with the assembled monks and bodhisattvas, as well as the fourfold assembly—monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen—and the entire world with its gods, humans, asuras, and gandharvas rejoiced with great delight and deeply praised the teaching of the Blessed One.They praised what the Blessed One had taught.Here Ends the Noble Perfection of Wisdom Vajra Cutter Great Vehicle Sutra.Namo Bhagavate Prajñāpāramitāye
OṂ NATA DATITA, ILI ŚI, ILI ŚI, MILI ŚI, MILI ŚI, BHINAYAN BHINAYAN
Namo Bhagavate Pratyaṃprate, IRITI, IRITI, MIRATI, MIRITI, ŚURITI, ŚURITI, UŚURI UŚURI, BHUYUYE BHUYUYE SVĀHĀIn the intrinsic nature of the Vajra Cutter, a view associated with attributes or marks is consciousness. This becomes equal.All phenomena arise from causes, their inherent nature is consciousness—
The Tathagata has explained this view of signs and their origin,
And likewise taught their complete cessation.
Thus speaks the Great Ascetic, whose wisdom is supreme.

incipit_title.en: The Sutra of the Great Vehicle Called the Diamond Cutter Word by Word
